entry.title: My Physical Goals
entry.content:
Eliminate my symptoms of femoroacetabular impingement.
Walk without stumbling over my right foot.
Sit on the floor comfortably in an L shape.
Correct lordosis when standing.
Correct kyphosis when sitting.
Reduce tension in my neck and shoulders.
Place palms comfortably on floor when standing with straight legs.
Clean muscle-ups.
Technical handstand.
Technical cartwheel without pain.
Technical roundoff without pain.
Consistent back tuck.
Consistent running front tuck.
Back handspring.
Side splits.
Front splits, both sides.

entry.title: Response to Matt Hsu from Upright Health

entry.content: Thank you! I greatly appreciate your comments and wish you all the best for 2016!

I really enjoyed your posts on Facebook. You May not knowing me by the way, lol. But I'm a fan of you. I knew you vía Long Haired Men Group. And believe me, you encouraged me to do things that I never thought I could make it. Words are not only words. They have truly power. And about your decisión to leave Facebook, I think it's okay. I did it once and I decided to return. And I keep on my list only to those peeps that I really know and want to be keep in touch. Just one word to describes what I feel, a Big Thank You for All your posts. And good luck for the next year. Be happy, Alex.

entry.title: Facebook Account Deactivated
entry.content:
I can always go back, but it's a great relief to be off Facebook.
It's been hard work, especially given how easy it is to use Facebook to log in to lots of websites, but with a bit of persistence you can make sure you don't lose anything.

Here's to a productive 2016!

entry.title: FAI Fix Schedule 2015
entry.content:
One of the biggest difficulties in following the FAI Fix is that it works so well.  This is a problem because I want to do everything, and have spent more time than I can afford doing tissue work and stretching.

Let's see how the following plan works out.  Feel free to take a copy and modify it for your own ends.

It's important to remember what external and internal rotation are, and what muscles are responsible for them. the internal rotators are generally in the inner thigh with the exception of the TFL. The external rotators are on the outside (posterior to greater trochanter). So when you do stretches to improve internal rotation, you'll often feel the resistance coming from the outer hip. When you stretch to improve external rotation, you'll feel the resistance in the inner thighs. [Thanks to Matt Hsu from Upright Health for the correction]

Printable Excel version
Printable LibreOffice version
Printable PDF 

This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.
Thanks for the correction!

entry.title: Hello, World: I Have FAI
entry.content:
Dragonfly at Melbourne Calisthenics
In spite of my best efforts, I have always had poor flexibility, lower back pain, tight hamstrings, and a general sense of helpless discomfort in my hips.  I am a very healthy, active, fit, 30-year-old man with a fine musculature and not a hint of a medical condition that would account for my physical problems.  And yet, something always seemed awry.

After probably 15 years of struggling with hip and leg flexibility, a parade of health specialists including doctors, physiotherapists, masseurs and masseuses, an acupuncturist, and everything in between, hundreds of hours, thousands of dollars, innumerable abortive attempts to improve in these areas, and a pervading sense that something just isn't working... I believe I know what's wrong.

An X-ray of both my hips, taken on the 15th of December 2014, reveals a femoro-acetabular impingement due to a large CAM lesion on the right femoral head and a small CAM lesion on the left femoral head.  As far as I can tell, both hip sockets are of normal shaped and width, so were it not for the lesions on both femoral heads I would have full range of flexion and rotation.

Furthermore, an ultrasound scan of my right hip does not reveal any damage or abnormality in the soft tissue around my right hip and groin, although an MRI (scheduled for Tuesday 23rd December) is required to investigate a labral tear.  I believe the labrum on my right hip is torn, quite possibly very badly, as I have suffered from chronic inflammation of the area for years.

Without efficacious treatment, I shall have arthritis in my right hip within a few years, and shall require hip replacement surgery at a pathetically early stage in my life.

As far as I can tell, the only efficacious treatment is surgery, and the best form of surgery is an arthroscopic osteoplasty to shave down the CAM lesion and chrondoplasty to repair the damaged labrum.  If the above be true, I require this procedure in both hips, but I do not yet know whether it is practicable or even feasible to have both hips treated in the same operation.  If so, I'd prefer to get it over and done with, but at the very least correcting the femoro-acetabular impingement in my right hip will buy me some time.

My plan is as follows:

PRE-OPERATION
  1. 23rd December 2014: Get an MRI to check for the extent of labral damage in my right hip
  2. 24th December 2014: Discuss the results with my doctor (general practitioner) and get a referral to a surgeon who specialises in the treatement of femoro-acetabular impingement.
  3. See said specialist and ascertain whether there is any reason I should NOT proceed with arthroscopic osteoplasty and chrondoplasty.
  4. Schedule the operation as soon as possible.
  5. Get in touch with the person who will give me post-operative rehabilitation exercises, learn what they are, and perform them daily in order to be as familiar with them as possible for my recovery.
POST-OPERATION
  1. Perform the rehabilitation exercises religiously.
  2. Avoid undue physical exertions.
  3. Focus on my work and studies.
  4. Regularly update my FAI blog and vlog.
    During this period, I will avoid activities that aggravate my condition, including ball sports, gymnastics, tricking, parkour, etc.
    However, I will maintain my routine of gentle running, dancing (swing, blues, zouk, salsa, bachata) and make my home away from home the Melbourne Calisthenics gym, run by my personal trainer, Alexander Jenkins, who is a knowledgeable athlete and a fine motivator  (http://www.melbournecalisthenics.com.au)
    Also, I have a book of introductory floor pilates exercises that I always meant to perform daily, so now is as good a time as any to incorporate them into my morning routine.

    Although I shall dearly miss my gymnastic activities, it is my heart's desire and my intention to build up my body with the view of returning to these pursuits by the end of 2015 and with a view to a happier, longer, pain-free life.

    FINAL THOUGHTS FOR TODAY
    I have many thoughts and feelings on this topic.  I hope that this blog will serve as a resource for other people suffering from this grossly undiagnosed condition, and provide encouragement to others who are going through it.

    Feel free to comment and get in touch with me.

    ---
    This is a journal entry from Alex's FAI Journal. For past and future posts, please visit http://faijournal.blogspot.com

entry.title: Open Letter to Matt Hsu and Shane Dowd at the FAI Fix, Christmas 2015
entry.content:
http://www.thefaifix.com
The following is addressed to Matt Hsu and Shane Dowd, the creators of The FAI Fix, and their subscribers.

Dear Matt and Shane,

This is a quick note to say thank you for the FAI Fix and the superb resources, especially on YouTube.
Ever since I started following the FAI Fix and the FAI Fix for Athletes, I have enjoyed heretofore unimaginable improvements in my mobility -- glutes, adductors, hamstrings, quads, calves, external hip rotators, TFL, lower back, shoulders -- and have really no need anymore of physiotherapy, massage, chiropractic, etc.
My motto these days is this: "I don't need therapy, I just need a kettlebell."
And best of all: my FAI is a thing of the past.
This time last year I would not have believed I could enjoy a fraction of what I have achieved in two months of focused, almost daily application of the principles you expostulate and the exercises you prescribe.  I have modified many other exercises for my own purposes and plan to expound them on this blog next year, so watch this space.

I have never in my adult life or teenage years felt as free and easy as I do these days, and I achieve an appreciable increase in static passive flexibility almost every session.
When I started using the gym for my self-treatment, I was looked on as a reclusive oddball who spent a lot of time on the floor; these days, gym members and even some of the trainers now approach me for advice on flexibility and stretching, because they can see I'm on to something special.
I have never been so excited and motivated to train, and I can barely contain myself when I consider the plethora of movement forms I shall be able to safely explore in my new, stronger, more mobile body.

Yes, the FAI Fix works, and if you go about it consistently and intelligently, it will work wonders.
For updates on my journey out of FAI Fix and into mobility, please subscribe to this RSS feed:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default/-/faijournal?alt=rss
Otherwise, you can subscribe to this blog in its entirety for musings on sundry topics according to my whim.

entry.title: Goodbye, Facebook, For Now...
entry.content:
As per my last post on the topic, I have decided to deactivate my account on Facebook.

There are many reasons for this decision, each one as good as the next, but my primary reason is to give The Odessia project everything I've got.

From Monday to Friday, I endeavour to maintain the following schedule:
  1. Put in an hour of focused, creative writing on The Odessia before going to work;
  2. Work conscientiously at my full-time job;
  3. Train every day at the gym for at least an hour and a half;
  4. Cook all my meals and keep house;
  5. Put in at least half an hour of further work on The Odessia.
  6. Be ready for bed by no later than 21:00.
And with my keen interest in a range of topics and my penchant for arguing with people online, I simply can't find a way to remain on Facebook without compromising this routine.  To put it another way, MORE than being on Facebook, I want to work well, stay fit, eat healthily, and pursue my dream of being a professional writer.

In this light it's a very simple decision.

Looking back, I was uninterested in Facebook until I got into swing dancing, at which point it became useful to me as a way of quasi-befriending people within the circles I moved in and staying up to date with social gatherings.  Later, as I built up a presence on YouTube, Facebook gave me a way of interacting with my subscribers, which I greatly enjoyed.  Over the last year, I have used my personal Facebook account to broadcast my philosophical and political views.  This has brought about two felicitous consequences:
Firstly, a great reduction in the number of Leftist ideologues (feminists, socialists, etc) willing to associate with me online;
Secondly, a modest increase in online association with those whom I hold in high esteem.

Nevertheless, arguing about politics online takes up more of my time than I can spare.

So now, at the end of 2015, the reasons for being on Facebook have mostly fallen away.

In the absence of Facebook, those I wish to remain in touch with can do so easily by the other means; as to staying up to date with developments in the world, RSS, YouTube, and Google will cover my needs; and if I find I have time for debating online, I'm sure there is no shortage of ways to do that -- although I suspect that I will have better things to do for the foreseeable future.

And of course I don't rule out the possibility of returning to Facebook one day, but my intention is to leave it for good. 

When I am online, I want either to expand my horizons, absorb useful information, enjoy something beautiful, or create content. (Such as this post!)

Here are the steps I have followed to prepare for a successful disengagement from Facebook:
1. Consolidate my blogs into this one. 
2. Set up RSS for blogs and Facebook pages I should like to follow. 
3. Use Evernote for quick memos, rather than status updates. 
4. Add birthdays of my true friends to my Google calendar 
5. Have an active Google+ account
6. Download my Facebook content

My plan is to deactive my account on New Year's Day 2016, but depending on how things go, I might do it sooner.  If you'd like to get in touch with me and haven't got any of my alternative contact details, leave a comment on this blog or message me via my profile and I will get in touch with you.

Let me know what you think of this decision and whether it encourages you to return to a quieter, simpler, slower pace of online life.

entry.title: Recap of My Talk with Shane Dowd
entry.content:
Jumping for joy...

This morning at 06:30am Melbourne time, I got to speak to Shane Dowd of the FAI Fix.  The time flew by for me, and a video should make its way to YouTube soon.

In the meantime, here is a recap of what I had to say:

My name is Alexander, I'm 31 years old, and live in Melbourne, Australia.  By day I am a security technician and by evening I am a mobility monk in the .  I am also the author of The Odessia (www.theodessia.com) and blog at mobilitymonk.blogspot.com.  I train primarily at Crossfit Moorabbin in the south-east of Melbourne and on some Saturday mornings you can find me at Crossfit Flatline in Geelong.

About a year ago, I started getting quite distressing pain in my right hip, which in retrospect was simply due to performing exercises without sufficient mobility or conditioning.  I have long since been interested in parkour, free-running, and tricking, and tried to build up slowly; however, even the fundamental kicks of tricking placed too much strain on my weak, tight groin -- hip flexors and adductors, mostly.  I want to the doctor, the doctor sent me for an X-ray, which "showed" I had a "cam" lesion on my right femoral head, and the irritation revealed by a subsequent MRI was used to support the diagnosis of femero-acetabular impingement.  The doctor recommended leading a more subdued life with less ambitious athletic goals and surgery to prevent arthritis.

My first attempt to fix the problem was to rest and get used to a sad life without the exciting physical pursuits I had dreamed of.  By that time I was already familiar with the work of Thomas Kurz and while attempting a wide deep squat, I gained an important insight.  If I depressed my right hip flexor with my thumb, I could squat without pain.  This showed me that the pain I felt had something to do with the muscles and connective tissue, not the bones.  It was a small insight, but it was very important.

I saw a link to Matt Hsu's channel, Upright Health, on an FAI sufferers' Facebook page.  Initially I was skeptical, but I decided to watch every video on his channel and critically examine what he had to say.  His argument made sense to me, and I also tried some of the exercises he demonstrated in his videos, with encouraging results.  I soon found out about the FAI Fix from there.  At any rate it would be at least six months, probably a year, before I would go into surgery, so why not give it a real go?

My experience of the FAI Fix has been of total success.  FAI is a thing of the past to me and I can't stress enough how important it is if you are thinking about surgery to properly try the FAI Fix.  The cost is a piddling fraction of surgery, and what have you got to lose?

I no longer feel any discomfort in my right hip and I have greater flexibility and mobility than ever before, not just the last couple of years.  The FAI Fix is really very simple: massage yourself, stretch, activate dormant muscles, and therein lies its genius.

My view of the FAI Fix is that it is actually a strength and flexibility training programme in disguise, and have built an entire method of training by synthesizing material from Thomas Kurz's tomes of sports science and the FAI Fix.  I am working on a manual that lays out this method, which I will publish soon.  By following this method, I have achieved enormous, transformative increases in flexibility and mobility in two months, far beyond my expectations.  I have never been flexible by any "stretch" of the imagination, but now gym members and even coaches approach me to ask for tips on flexibility.  I have no accreditation or formal training, but everyone can see that I'm doing something right.  As my flexibility gains translate into more eye-catching compound stretches, I expect interest to grow.
What has worked for me?  Really everything in the FAI Fix.  Where there is a choice of exercises, some work better than others, but they are all excellent and can be enhanced by adding weight or resistance.  An important fact of the stretching and tissue work is that it is an exercise in regulating anxiety, distress, and frustration.  Tissue work can be very painful, and if you fear the pain, it will hurt you.  Stretching is even more distressing in my experience -- or rather used to be -- because most places are populated by people who seem to stretch effortlessly and painlessly.  For me, it was humiliating and frustrating to be so limited and in so much pain, which of course only made it worse.  It was when the pain of the tissue work gave way to relief and the stretching actually worked, that I began to enjoy it.  It's still not easy, but it is satisfying where before it was distressing.

Words of advice and encouragement: 
The FAI Fix will solve your FAI in the same way lifting weights will make you strong -- if you do it properly.  Remember this: if you have FAI it's because you DID NOT LISTEN to your body.  It's harsh but true; however, it's definitely not too late.

Buy a cheap notebook and a pen, find a local gym where you don't feel self-conscious, and make time in your schedule to go there every day.  Don't say you'll do it at home, there's always a distraction there.  Don't get a personal trainer.  Spend time on your own, listen to your own body until you hear what it's been trying to tell you all these years.  I won't pretend to sound reasonable or conciliatory by saying "a couple times a week or whenever you can fit it in" -- NO, you only have one body and one life, and it's time to start living it to the full.

entry.title: Improve Your Posture Dramatically With This One Easy Tip!
entry.content:
There is an oft repeated parable about a young man who asks a wise elder for one principle to live by, rather than a whole set of rules. The elder tells him never to tell a lie. The young man, thinking that this injunction permits him to engage in licentiousness and dishonourable conduct, readily promises to follow this advice.
However, the young man soon discovers that without the option of lying about his deeds, he has to bear the full cost of his misdeeds, which soon become more trouble than they are worth. And so, even though he intended to live indulgently and decadently, his oath of honesty forced him on to a path of virtuous restraint. And, if you're wondering, the young man lead a full and happy life.

In my own life, I am always on the lookout for simple adjustments to my daily routine that make me stronger, fitter, more alert, and more balanced. And of late a seemingly small but momentous change presents itself to me:

Quit Facebook.

"What do you mean? Surely not to leave Facebook altogether! "

Yes, that's what I mean. Think about it:
How much time per day, per week, per month, do you spend on Facebook, hunched over your phone or slouching at your computer? What would you do if you had all that time back? How would your posture, your breathing, your sleeping patterns, your creative energy, your hips and back and shoulders all fare?

Moreover, given my predilection for arguing with people online and collecting amusing memes, being on Facebook simply takes too much time away from all the other things I want to do in the hours available to me outside work: working on The Odessia and other writing endeavours, keeping house, working out at the gym, getting to sleep early, making videos on YouTube, blogging, etc.

In addition to that, I find it harder to clear my mind and remain in a state of equanimity when I have spent time on Facebook.  My writing suffers for this, and I suspect that other intellectual endeavours are as well.

"If it's simple, why don't you quit Facebook today?"

Because Facebook has become useful and convenient in the following respects:
  1. Keeping in touch with friends
  2. Getting invitations to parties and sundry social gatherings
  3. News, opinion pieces, blog posts
  4. Online discussions
  5. Broadcasting my own content
"So what are you going to do about it?"

In order not to be dragged back to Facebook, I have to find alternatives.
The following alternatives may be useful to you.

KEEPING IN TOUCH WITH FRIENDS
  1. Email
  2. Skype
  3. Google Hangouts
  4. Voxer

INVITATIONS TO EVENTS AND GATHERINGS
  1. Have meaningful friendships
  2. Ask to be invited by email

NEWS, OPINION PIECES, BLOG POSTS
  1. RSS
  2. Subscription by email
  3. Voxer
  4. YouTube

ONLINE DISCUSSIONS
  1. Google Hangouts
  2. Voxer
  3. Skype
  4. Comments threads of blog posts
  5. Message boards

BROADCASTING MY OWN CONTENT
  1. Keep a blog
  2. Keep a YouTube channel
  3. Use Twitter

"Alright, when will you take the plunge?"

First, I will dust off my blogs,  make sure they're shipshape, and collect them all into one main blog.
Next, I will download all my photos and content from Facebook.
Next, I will put together a final post outlining my decision to deactivate my Facebook account for the foreseeable future, and call on people who wish to stay in touch to contact me.
Then one week after that post I will deactivate my account.

Wish me luck!

This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone. Also, check out the FAI Fix: http://www.thefaifix.com

entry.title: Rolfing and Skepticism
entry.content:
The Status Quo


There are two competing theories about FAI:
  1. Pincer impingement and/or CAM lesion.  The reason I get pain when I squat or kick is that the CAM lesion on my right femoral head hits against the acetabulam and may have already caused labral damage.  The only efficacious solution is a surgical operation, namely arthroscopic osteoplasty and possibly chrondoplasty.
  2. Muscular weakness, resulting in hypertension and/or hypermobility in the muscles governing the movements that cause me pain.  This can be corrected over time through alternative treatment and a tailored exercise programme.
At this stage in my battle with FAI (femoroalacetabular impingement), I am on the path to surgery, which is likely to happen in mid-2015 or late 2015.  In the meantime, I will seriously consider every credible alternative to surgery.

Goals

Before I go on, I must explicate what I'm doing all this for.

Prevention of Injury and Degeneration


Flexibility

 

Balance and Strength

Peace of Mind

Alternatives To Surgery

Self-treatment

A particularly good proponent of the view that FAI symptoms can be overcome is

Rolfing


 
  1. Self-treatment



I am considering paying for a course of Rolfing treatment.  From what I have read, it promises to help me progress in areas that have long eluded me.

However, before I put down good money for this, I need to establish what standards and tests apply here.

I, like many others, have all too often fallen into the trap of delivering myself into the hands of a practitioner whose treatment is of limited efficacy.  Unless there is very clear evidence of a fault or physical defect that cannot be corrected without somebody's intervention, I owe it to myself to explore all the possibilities for self-treatment and self-correction.

At this stage in my battle with FAI (femoroalacetabular impingement), I am on the path to surgery, which is likely to happen in mid-2015 or late 2015.  In the meantime, I will seriously consider every credible alternative to surgery



A good starting point for any alternative treatment is to see what the critics and skeptics have to say about it:
http://skepdic.com/rolfing.html
http://www.npr.org/2010/12/06/131735132/rolfing-back-in-vogue-but-with-shaky-evidence
http://galwayskeptics.blogspot.com.au/2011/04/have-you-been-rolfed.html
http://skeptics.stackexchange.com/questions/16664/is-rolfing-an-effective-treatment-for-bad-posture
http://debunkatron.com/
http://www.dailystrength.org/health_blogs/teamds/article/rolfing-a-massage-that-hurts-but-helps
http://www.internationalskeptics.com/forums/showthread.php?t=80784







This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.

entry.title: How To Become More "Flexible"
entry.content:
Most of us would like to be more "flexible", but most people (as far as I can tell) do not know what this means.

Definitions

Do you want to swing your leg higher in football or dancing? Bend over further? Swing your arm out further? Twist and turn through a greater range? That's dynamic flexibility.
This football player was stretching very dynamically; no external resistance here.
Do you want to achieve the splits or go flat on the floor in a static stretch?  That's static passive flexibility.
Thomas Kurz, an oracle of flexibility. 
Do you want to raise your leg high and keep it up in the air? That's static active flexibility.
This martial artists are keeping their legs up in the air without assistance.
Although they are related, each type of flexibility is different and must be trained for specifically.

Your static passive flexibility in a given range is as far as you can go, with all the assistance from external force that your body will permit.  Your dynamic and static active ranges are a subset of your static passive range, and most people's flexibility can be represented by this venn diagramme:


What This Means For You

To Increasing Dynamic Flexibility

  1. Maximise your dynamic flexibility within your current static passive range through dynamic stretching; OR
  2. Increase your static passive range through PNF stretching AND dynamic stretching
This will allow you to kick higher, swing your arm out wider, bend and twist further in a movement, etc.

To Increase Static Passive Flexibility

  1. Maximise your static active flexibility within your current static passive range through static active stretching; OR
  2. Increase your static passive range AND static active stretching
This will allow you to hold your leg up higher without assistance, reach out further with your arm, bend and twist in a static position further.

To Increase Your Static Passive Range

  1. Condition the muscle with resistance training through the entire range of motion.
  2. Static passive stretching.
  3. P.N.F. (proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation) of stretching, commonly known as "contract-release".
This will both increase your potential in the other two categories and translate into getting deeper and wider in your stretches -- splits, bends, bridges, etc.

Defining Your Goals

What does all this mean in practice?

It usually means that, in addition to maximising your dynamic and static active flexibility, you want to increase your static passive range.

Not only do you want to kick higher, you want to do the splits; not only do you want to bend further in dancing, you want to do a bridge, etc.

Not only will achieving these static passive stretches give you a greater tensile range to work with, but they are milestones in and of themselves.

So How Do I Get There?

A good start would be a previous post of mine on the topic:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/2015/12/isolated-stretches-vs-compound-stretches.html

And of course, to familiarise yourself with the work of Thomas Kurz:
https://tomkurz.wordpress.com

And finally, a great system for getting to know your limitations and how to overcome them is the FAI Fix developed by Matt Hsu at Upright Health and Shane Dowd at Legacy Athletics:
https://www.thefaifix.com

Further Definitions

The following definitions are taken from Thomas Kurz's book, Stretching Scientifically:

Flexibility: Flex + Ability = Flexibility. Where as Flex is to bend or to resist breaking, and Ability is a skill or talent. Flexibility becomes the skill of controlling the range of motion and movement capacity of your physical structure. Flexibility is developed by special exercises called stretches, which involve the elongation of muscles, connective tissues, and other tissues.

Types of flexibility

There are six types of flexibility. They are classified based on the muscle's action and whether or not there is an external force acting to maintain or aid an increase in the range of motion. They include:
  1. Dynamic active flexibility (just using the muscles of the moving body part);
  2. Dynamic passive flexibility below the pain threshold (only using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless limit of motion);
  3. Dynamic passive flexibility over the pain threshold and up to pain tolerance (using as much external assistance as needed to reach the maximal limit of motion permitted by pain tolerance);
  4. Static active flexibility (just using the muscles of the stretched body part to hold a stretched position);
  5. Static passive flexibility below the pain threshold (only using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless maximum stretch); and
  6. Static passive flexibility up to pain tolerance (using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless maximal stretch permitted by pain tolerance).

entry.title: Isolated Stretches vs Compound Stretches
entry.content:
In three months, even though I have not spent a single minute on the front splits, I have improved my range in the front splits at least as much as this fellow here:

http://antranik.org/90-days-splits-challenge-results/
How have I achieved such an increase in static passive flexibility without training for this movement?

Through consistent application of isolated stretches to the muscles along the chain.

A very common approach to stretching is to prescribe compound stretches [movements that require a high degree of mobility throughout a chain of muscles] to people who cannot perform them.
Nowhere else in physical training is this approach taken: compound resistance exercises are broken down into their components, technical skills are built up from their components, and wherever you look, a competent trainer will "break it down" for you and help you to piece it together.

But flexibility training is all to often an exercise in futility.

If you, like me, have always had poor flexibility, imagine going to a class of adult gymnastics and being asked to follow the supple gymnasts who move easily through demanding compound stretches.  How has that worked out for you?  Are you any better?  Or do you simply accept that stretching is meant to be frustrating and humiliating for you?  Have you been sold the "onion ring" theory, that the restriction in various muscle groups will over time "peel away", and one day, over the rainbow, you will move freely throughout the compound stretch?

This makes no sense whatsoever to me.

My approach is to use a compound stretch to identify where the restriction is, and once I have found it, to laser in on it with the following:
  1. Resistance training
  2. Tissue work
  3. Targeted stretching
For example, if you are to achieve the front splits, you need a considerable range of motion in the following:
  1. Quadriceps
  2. Adductors
  3. Hamstrings
  4. Calves
  5. Glutes
If you are restricted in any of these areas, you will find yourself very far off the ground, unable to progress.  If you try to do the splits without targetting each and every area, you will simply spend a lot of time wobbling in the air, feeling silly.  Moreover, your nervous system will not permit you to relax in this pose and any significant increase in range of motion, if to be achieved at all, will be done extremely inefficiently.  Add to that bruising and discomfort from sustained pressure on joints (especially your knees) that bear your weight because you can't move far enough in the stretch to get off them.

Over the past couple of months I have been cycling through each of the major areas with targeted resistance training, targeted tissue work, and targeted stretching.
  1. Quadriceps
  2. Adductors
  3. Hamstrings
  4. Glutes
  5. External hip rotators
  6. Calves
  7. Hip flexors
I work towards specific goals for each muscle group, and have sought static stretches that permit the greatest degree of relaxation, application of external resistance, and the easiest enhancement by means of PNF. (Proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation)

And the result?  A huge increase in range of motion, stronger muscles, and the confidence that comes with following a rational, science-based system of training.  When I achieve the splits -- without training specifically for it --, I will append photos to the end of this post.

You must do what you feel is the right course for you. I wish you all the best and I look forward to the further incarnations of the Odessia. Please keep me posted on all updates with the project. Much success and happiness, Alex.

entry.title: Defining the Problem and Defining Success
entry.content:
The Problems

Pain, Discomfort, Hypertension, Inactivity

Sumo squat pain

When I try to perform a sumo squat, I get pain in the muscle directly over my right hip.

Right hamstring

My right hamstring is perennially tight.

Right gluteal muscles

When I perform the "superman", my right gluteal muscles do not activate and the load of lifting my right leg and holding it up is taken over by my right lower back and right hamstring.

Right calf muscles

Both sets of calf muscles are probably quite tight, but if I am dehydrated and sleep deprived, my right calf muscle may spasm in the night, and remain tender for the following days unless treated.

Right shoulder

My right shoulder often gets tight and is especially uncomfortable when I am driving.

Neck

I have a lot of tension in my neck, resulting in numerous clicks through the vertebrae if I rotate my neck sharply to the right or left.  (More often to the right)

Trapezoid Muscles

Quite strong and perennially tight.  I have a habit of shrugging in the Gallic manner and need to remind myself to relax those muscles.

Scapulae

My scapulae are very inactive and seem to be engaged only when I consciously do so.

Restricted Range of Motion

Rounded back when sitting on the floor

Sitting on the floor with my legs crossed.
Sitting on the floor with my legs straight out.

Rounded back and collapsed frame when sitting in a chair

Rounded back and limited internal hip rotation when sitting in "executive" pose

Lordosis when standing and dancing, but not when jogging or running*

Right calf gets tight and tends to spasm if I'm dehydrated

Hip dysplacia/tension

When I try to internally rotate my hip, the same muscle that I feel pain in during the sumo squat remains tense and sore.

My Goals

1. Deep sumo squat with my feet double the width of my shoulders.


Thomas Kurz in his fifties, showing how it's done.

2. Side Splits

Thomas Kurz in his fifties, showing how it's done.

3. Front Splits, both sides

Thomas Kurz in his thirties, demonstrating front splits

 4. Back Bridge, full extension of arms and legs



5. Sitting comfortably with my legs crossed, straight back

6. Sitting comfortably in the lotus position

7. Sitting comfortably with my legs extended and back
straight

8. Touch the floor with the palms of my hands, straight legs

9. Stand comfortably without lordosis

10. Achieve body position for handstand

11. Pancake with legs splayed at least 90 degrees

12. Pancake with splits

13. Pancake with legs straight out




This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.

entry.title: My Training Schedule On A Single A5 Page
entry.content: Spent a bit of time on my lunch break putting this together.

entry.title: Sinister Dexterity or Dextrous Sinisterness: Pick Things Up With Your Other Hand
entry.content:
I being right-handed, it has always been my habit to pick things up with right hand.  This means it has always been my habit to place my weight on my right foot, bend over my right side, reach with my right arm, etc.  If something be on the floor, that means lunging with my right foot forward -- always my right foot forward -- or squatting with my weight over my right foot... You get the idea.

In light of this thought, a week ago I made a conscious decision to pick things up with my left hand as much as possible, if not exclusively.

After a week I can report the following:
  1. My left quads are getting much more of a work-out every day.
  2. The chain of muscles running all the way from my left hip to my left hand has been getting much more of a work out every day.
  3. I am getting better at balancing on my left foot.
  4. I am developing a better sense of what my left hip does when I move in my daily life.
As to the title, "dexter" means right and "sinister" left in Latin.  The sense of skillfulness in dexterous comes from the recognition that most people (nine out of ten, I am told) are better at doing things with their right hands.  This gives us such expressions as "right-hand man" and "to be on the right side" of things. The sense of malevolence in sinister comes from the superstitious association of bad omens, evil, and inferiority with the left hand side of things.

Therefore, in my coinage, to train your left side is to develop "sinister dexterity"; conversely, to train your right, "dexterous sinisterness".  Those who understand the joke should be valued as life-long friends.

This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.
s commenting to keep in touch, dear. And I am the blonde, sheesh :) Happy New Year, and all that jazz. Hugs

entry.title: Using Dynamic Stretches To Identify Muscle Weakness and Impingement
entry.content:
A demonstration of the dynamic stretches that I try to do every day.  I didn't demonstrate the lateral leg swings or some others, because my right hamstring was tight.




To release my hamstring, I activated my lower back and also did a modified clam shell glute activation exercise. (Not shown in the video)

As you can see, once I had done those two exercises, my hamstrings allowed me full range of motion, even to the degree of placing my palms on the floor with my feet at shoulder width and my legs straight.  I noticed that activating the quads helped with that, which makes sense, as they are the opposing muscles to the hamstrings.

I was very pleased to get a full range of motion in my front leg swings, as it is one of my favourite warm up exercises.

PROBLEMS:

I noticed quite severe arching of my back in my arm swings.
I'll add a basic gymnastic dish exercise to my warm up and see if that helps.

For a superb resource on this, check out Thomas Kurz's blog: http://tomkurz.wordpress.com/

This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.

entry.title: Stretch Therapy Session #1 at Melbourne Physical & Natural Studio (16th January 2015)
entry.content:
Friday, 16th January 2015.

I am encouraged by my first session with Graeme Shrapnel at Melbourne Physical & Natural Studio.  After I gave Graeme an overview of what had brought me to him -- hip impingement, tight right hamstring, tendency towards lordosis when standing, slouching when sitting -- he used a detailed 3D representation of muscles on his computer screen to point out the areas he would initially investigate.  He has clearly built up a professional understanding of physiology in theory and in practice.

After my treatment, I felt remarkably relaxed and light.  Graeme's assessment directly addressed my pain points and gives me hope that there is a credible alternative to surgical treatment of my femoro-acetabular impingement.

Graeme's studio is affiliated with Kit Laughlin, whose YouTube videos are an excellent source of information for anyone interested in stretching, FAI, or just general wellbeing:


(Preliminary) Conclusion
As I have only been there once, it is too early to make an appraisal of the efficacy of stretch therapy. Nevertheless, Graeme is has given me most of what I specifically asked for:
  1. A detailed assessment of the defects in my posture and muscular imbalances.
  2. A set of exercises to ameliorate this condition.
  3. A space in which I can essay this approach.
The only thing I'd have liked further is a written definition of the goals and a timeline of my treatment, but I can define my goals as simply to correct the below-listed defects; and, given the unquantifiable variables of my own body, it is probably impossible to say how long it'll take for me to see significant results.

At any rate, I will do these exercises every day and update this blog post with my thoughts and observations.

Assessment

  • Right psoas muscle is weak, stiff, and shortened.
  • Piriformis muscles, both left and right, are tight and short.
  • Right hip is rotated forward.
  • Right leg seems slightly shorter on account of hip tension.
  • Tendency towards anterior pelvic tilt.
  • Right quadriceps muscles are stronger than the left.

Treatment (once a day)

Hip Flexor Stretch

Instructions

1 set x 5 reps (building up to 10 over the course of a week)

Lying backwards on floor, resting on elbows.
Raise straight leg up and out, at about 45 degree angle.
Slowly lower the leg to the floor whilst counting slowly to 10.
Repeat on the other side.

Thoughts and Observations

When I tried it in my session, my upper hip flexor got tired after four repetitions.

Pectoral and Biceps Stretch

Instructions

  1. Lie face down on the floor.
  2. Extend left arm slightly above shoulder, rotate hand forward to face thumb towards your chest.
  3. Right hand placed flat on floor close to shoulder, elbow up.
  4. Push on right hand and slowly roll over outstretched arm, rolling right back over left, to increase the stretch.
  5. Hold for 30 seconds.
  6. Repeat on the other side.

Thoughts and Observations

An excellent stretch that I will do often, as I spend a lot of time on the floor anyway.

Piriformis Stretch and External Hip Rotation (chair version)

Instructions

  1. Sitting on the edge of the chair, supporting foot flat on the floor, place ankle of other leg across knee of supporting leg.
  2. Draw navel to spine lifting up chest to straighten back and angle hips forward.
  3. Take a deep breath; as you breathe incline your body towards your top foot, bending only at the hips.
  4. To come out of the stretch, push back with both arms.

Thoughts and Observations

I get pins on needles in my right leg when stretching my right side. 
My right side also relaxes less readily than my left.
As my hips are very tight, I need to bend my supporting leg quite a bit.

Buttocks and Hip Flexor Stretch

Instructions

  1. Start in a wide kneeling lunge, square hips facing forward, relax muscles around the waist and gently increase the lunge.
  2. Deep breath, on out, lift chest and extend torso forward on to hands.
  3. Two contractions: press foot into floor and draw backwards towards buttocks.  At the same time, press hands into floor, draw back lifting chest.
  4. Deep breath, on out, left and extend chest forwards moving on to elbows, raise back foot on to toes straighten back leg.  (Knee off the floor)
  5. Hold position for 30 seconds.
  6. Lift back on to hands keeping back leg straight.
  7. Contract buttock of back leg, lift chest and slowly push hip of back leg towards the floor.
  8. To come out of the stretch, drop  your back leg to the floor, sit for a while in relaxed Cossack stretch, and push up with your hands to stand up.

Thoughts and Observations

Nothing to add at the moment.

Upper Thoracic Stretch

  1. Standing position, arms behind back, fingers laced and palms together.
  2. Deep breath, on breath out, draw hands down over buttocks, arching back slightly, and contract muscles behind shoulder to draw them together. (Scapular retraction)
  3. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat 3 times.

Thoughts and Observations

 This is an excellent stretch, which can be done throughout the day, especially after working on the computer.  I intend to do this stretch at work and make a habit of doing it after driving in the car as well.  (I'd like to write a separate blog post about stretches to do after getting out of the car)

Seated Lumbar Stretch

  1. Sit on floor -- soles of feet together and knees bent.
  2. Hands placed near ankles.
  3. Draw navel towards the spine.
  4. Maintain a straight back, bend from hips, lift up chest and draw chest towards feet.
  5. Hold stretch about 10 seconds.
  6. (C) Clasp feet and draw torso forwards.
  7. (R) Deep breath, on out breath lift chest and draw towards feet.
  8. Hold stretch for 30 seconds.

Thoughts and Observations

Nothing to add at the moment.

Kneeling Hamstring Stretch

Instructions

  1. Commence in a left side kneeling lunge.
  2. Bend forward at hip, placing chest on right thigh.
  3. Slowly stretch right leg to feel stretch in hamstring. (10 seconds)
  4. (C) Contract muscles gently by pushing right into floor. (5 seconds)
  5. (R) Relax and take a deep breath.
  6. On breathing out, straighten leg a little further, maintain chest-to-thigh contact.
  7. This can be achieved sliding foot forward or moving bottom backwards.
  8. Hold for 30 seconds.
  9. Repeat on the other side.
  10. At completion of stretch give legs a little shake.

Thoughts and Observations

 This is by far one of the most difficult stretches I have performed.  My right hamstring is perennially tight -- this is one of the reasons that brought me to Graeme -- but beyond this source of pain, performing this stretch makes me feel upset.  I believe that a lot of negative emotions (owing to trauma in childhood) are stored in my muscles, especially my lower back, and deep stretches of muscles that attach to the core of my nervous system will induce waves of anxiety, anger, or distress.  After completing the stretch on both sides, I needed a minute to calm down, and thereafter I felt that it had been cathartic.  Graeme said that a lot of people report going through this tempest during these deep stretches.  At any rate, I'm fascinated to find out how I get along doing this stretch over the next few weeks.

Scapular Retraction on Chin-up Bar

Instructions

  1. Hang from a bar with your arms straight.
  2. Draw your attention to your scapulae and try to squeeze them together.

Thoughts and Observations

In order to retract my scapulae, I really have to engage the muscles from the top of shoulders all the way down the chain to my shoulder blades.  I don't know if it is possible to squeeze my shoulder blades together in isolation, but maybe the point of the exercise is to recruit all of the muscle that work to keep your shoulders up and stable, rather than slouching.

***
